content.instruction:
Interaction between humans and the environment

SUBTHEMES

  • Demography and Disease
  • Migration
  • Patterns of Settlement
  • Technology

hotspots.hotspot:
Demography

The word demography refers to the study of human populations, such as the number of people living in an area, how fast or slow the population is growing, the number of old versus young people, and other statistics.

Migration

The term migration means "the movement of people from place to place."

Patterns of Settlement

The phrase patterns of settlement refers to similarities in where villages and cities arose, such as near rivers or trade routes or coal deposits. It also refers to the different ways that cities formedâ€”in a square or grid pattern, for example, or as a round cluster of homes.

Technology

The word technology refers to putting knowledge to practical use. The spear and wheelbarrow, for example, were great technological inventions.

scene.credits: (tr)Tetra Images/Getty Images, (c)Adam Jones/Corbis, (bkgd)Kathy Collins/Photographer's Choice RF/Getty Images.

hotspots.hotspot:
Mongols & Merchants

During the 1340s, Mongols, merchants, and other travelers spread the disease known as bubonic plague along trade routes from China to Black Sea ports. Some historians believe that 20 million Chinese died from the deadly bacteria carried by fleas.

Black Death

Italian merchant ships carrying flea-infested rats brought the bubonic plague from Black Sea ports to Europe. There, the disease became known as the Black Death because victims developed black lumps before dying. Roughly 25 percent of Europeans died from the disease as it swept through crowded cities and into villages.

Explorers & Smallpox

Explorers to the Americas and Pacific Islands introduced smallpox and other diseases to native peoples. Between 1500 and 1800, some 100 million people may have died during epidemics in these regions.

scene.credits: (tr)Tetra Images/Getty Images, (bkgd)Kathy Collins/Photographer's Choice RF/Getty Images.

multiple.question: Which of these statements about historical epidemics is true?

answers.answer: The bubonic plague killed more people in China than smallpox did in the Americas and Pacific.
Smallpox was spread through bacteria-infected fleas.
The Black Death spread through trade, and spread quickly due to crowded and dirty cities.
Roughly half of Europe's population died from the Black Death.

scene.credits: (tr)Tetra Images/Getty Images, (bkgd)Kathy Collins/Photographer's Choice RF/Getty Images.

(tr)Tetra Images/Getty Images, (l)Danita Delimont/Gallo Images/Getty Images, (tc)Melba Photo Agency/PunchStock, (bc)Universal Images Group/Getty Images, (bkgd)Kathy Collins/Photographer's Choice RF/Getty Images.

Click to Explore

Click on the 'hot spots' to view additional information.

activity.text:
In the murky world of the spy . . . the French suspected [Mata Hari] of being a double agent. In February 1917 Mata Hari returned to Paris and was immediately arrested; charged with being a German spy. Her trial in July revealed some damning evidence that the dancer was unable to adequately explain. She was convicted and sentenced to death.

In the early-morning hours of October 15, Mata Hari was awakened and taken by car from her Paris prison cell to an army barracks on the city's outskirts where she was to meet her fate.

Henry Wales was a British reporter who covered the execution.

"Mata Hari was not bound and she was not blindfolded. She stood gazing steadfastly at her executioners, when the priest, the nuns, and her lawyer stepped away from her.

The officer in command of the firing squad, who had been watching his men like a hawk that none might examine his rifle and try to find out whether he was destined to fire the blank cartridge which was in the breech of one rifle, seemed relieved that the business would soon be over."

Credit: Copyright © 2005 EyeWitnesstoHistory.com

hotspots.hotspot:
Inference

Spies must be common throughout history, because this text suggests that there is a "world" surrounding this occupation.

Inference

Mata Hari is an unusual name for a woman in France. The text a few lines down says she is a dancer. Maybe "Mata Hari" is a stage name.

Inference

February 1917 means this occurred during World War I.

Inference

Mata Hari must have been famous if a British reporter is covering her death.

Inference

Evidently, most people killed by firing squad are first bound and blindfolded.

Inference

It must be common practice for church members to accompany an execution. Or perhaps Mata Hari was Catholic.

Inference

One member of a firing squad is given a blank cartridge. Why? Maybe to lessen the guilt of killing a human being.

scene.credits: (tr)Tetra Images/Getty Images, (bkgd)Kathy Collins/Photographer's Choice RF/Getty Images.
(tr)Tetra Images/Getty Images, (bkgd)Kathy Collins/Photographer's Choice RF/Getty Images.
(tr)Tetra Images/Getty Images, (l)Leemage/Universal Images Group/Getty Images, (r)Roberto Schmidt/AFP/Getty Images, (bkgd)Kathy Collins/Photographer's Choice RF/Getty Images.

content.text:
Alexander the Great "had great personal beauty, invincible power of endurance, and a keen intellect; he was brave and adventurous, strict in the observance of his religious duties, and hungry for fame. . . . Noble indeed was his power of inspiring his men, of filling them with confidence, and, in the moment of danger, of sweeping away their fear by the spectacle of his own fearlessness. . . .

Doubtless, in the passion of the moment Alexander sometimes erred; it is true that he took some steps toward the pomp and arrogance of the Asiatic kings: but I, at least, cannot feel that such errors were very heinous, if the circumstances are taken fairly into consideration. For, after all, he was young . . . [and he was] sorry for his mistakes. . . ."

Credit: From THE CAMPAIGNS OF ALEXANDER by Arrian, translated by Aubrey de Selincourt, published by Penguin.

scene.credits: (tr)Tetra Images/Getty Images, (bkgd)Kathy Collins/Photographer's Choice RF/Getty Images.

content.text:
Narrative of Events [on May 2, 1992, in the city of Sarajevo]: Fighting erupted in the morning after Serb mortar shells began falling near the city's old Muslim quarter. A major artillery attack began soon after 1:00 P.M. and fighting continued well into the night. Mortar and tank shells were fired for hours directly into the main business and shopping district. . . . Hundreds of people walking in the downtown area were caught in the streets when the attack began. They ran for shelter into bars, basements, and entrance halls. . . . At dusk, with the fighting continuing, reporters on the scene described blazing government buildings, bodies of fighters and civilians lying on the street for hours after the fighting began, artillery and mortar shells coming from the hills, and of close-range fighting in the narrow alleys of . . . the old Muslim city.

Credit: "Annex VI: Study of the Battle and Siege of Sarajevo," Final Report of the United Nations Commission of Experts Established Pursuant to Security Council Resolution 780 (1992). (United Nations document S/1994/674/Add.2 (Vol. II), 28 December 1994).

scene.credits: (tr)Tetra Images/Getty Images, (bkgd)Kathy Collins/Photographer's Choice RF/Getty Images.

multiple.question: How do we know that this excerpt is a secondary source?

answers.answer: It was written by someone at the scene.
It was relayed to the writer by a person at the scene.
It is a summary found in a UN document.
It supports what is viewed in the photograph.

figure.text:
Narrative of Events [on May 2, 1992, in the city of Sarajevo]: Fighting erupted in the morning after Serb mortar shells began falling near the city's old Muslim quarter. A major artillery attack began soon after 1:00 P.M. and fighting continued well into the night. Mortar and tank shells were fired for hours directly into the main business and shopping district. . . . Hundreds of people walking in the downtown area were caught in the streets when the attack began. They ran for shelter into bars, basements, and entrance halls. . . . At dusk, with the fighting continuing, reporters on the scene described blazing government buildings, bodies of fighters and civilians lying on the street for hours after the fighting began, artillery and mortar shells coming from the hills, and of close-range fighting in the narrow alleys of . . . the old Muslim city.

Credit: "Annex VI: Study of the Battle and Siege of Sarajevo," Final Report of the United Nations Commission of Experts Established Pursuant to Security Council Resolution 780 (1992). (United Nations document S/1994/674/Add.2 (Vol. II), 28 December 1994).

scene.credits: (tr)Tetra Images/Getty Images, (bkgd)Kathy Collins/Photographer's Choice RF/Getty Images.

hotspots.hotspot:
Multiple Choice

Your score is based on the number of questions you answer correctly. Points are not deducted for incorrect answers, so you should answer all of the questions, even if you do not know the answer.

Free Response

Budget your time to complete all three questions. You are expected to provide historical evidence and use examples in your answers.

scene.credits: (tr)Tetra Images/Getty Images, (bkgd)Kathy Collins/Photographer's Choice RF/Getty Images.

multiple.question: History, or the time when humans began to write, occurred about 5,000 years ago.
The spear and wheelbarrow are examples of technology.
Demographics is the study of human populations.
On the AP Exam, you should not answer the questions you do not know.
You may receive college credit if you perform well on the AP Exam.
